results.title: Harold and Maude
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Colin Higgins, Charles Mulvehill and Hal Ashby
results.brief_description: Harold, a depressed rich teenager obsessed with death - his favourite pastime is performing elaborate mock suicides - is liberated by his intimate friendship with Maude, an 80 year old holocaust survivor and funeral follower. A classic free spirit, Maude is the polar opposite of the gloomy Harold. Her passion for life despite the blows it has dealt her, eventually cures Harold of his teenage angst. Like Bob Rafelson, a director similarly obsessed with the trials and tribulations of the children of the rich, Ashby forever treads the thin line between whimsy and absurdity, ‘tough’ sentimentality and black comedy. A doggedly eccentric film, it garnered a cult following in the seventies that persists today. Cast includes Ruth Gordan, Bud Cort, Vivian Pickles and Cyril Cusack.

results.title: Harlequin
results.creator_credit: FG Films, Far Flight, Antony Ginnane and Simon Wincer
results.brief_description: An influential politician and his wife fall prey to a man who saves the life of their son. He is a hypnotic faith healer called Wolf “The Harlequin” and his powers of manipulation are strong. A chief political adviser to the the politican attempts to remove “The Harlequin” and lessen his power but is confronted by a being with strong supernnatural powers. The climax is filled with unbelievable tension and terror. Starring David Hemmings, Robert Powell, Broderick Crawford and Carmen Duncan.

results.title: Harlan County USA
results.creator_credit: Cabin Creek Films and Barbara Kopple
results.brief_description: A cinema verite account of a coal miners’ strike in Harlan, Kentucky between 1973 and 1974 when the miners at the Brookside Mine fought for the right to join the Mine Workers’ Union of America. The film shows the major events of the strike; the confrontation between management and employees, the gun-slinging scabs, picketing miners’ wives, and violence and murder. It also shows that organised labour can be corrupt as can managements, as illustrated by the fight for union leadership. Rated: PG

results.title: Hard target
results.creator_credit: Alphaville, Renaissance Productions, James Jacks, Sean Daniel and John Woo
results.brief_description: Chance Boudreaux (Jean Claude Van Damme) is a down on his luck Cajun soldier, reluctantly hired by Nat Binder (Yancy Butler) to help find her father, an ex Green Beret who is currently homeless in Louisiana. What they both don’t know is that their mission is doomed to fail, as Nat’s father has been brutally murdered as sport. His killer is the ruthless Fouchon (Lance Henriksen), a mercenary who procures homeless people living around New Orleans and enlists them in his game, whereby they become the live targets. This film features enough of John Woo’s trademark action and Jean Claude Van Damme’s physical presence to satisy Woo and JCVD fans.

results.title: Happy go lovely
results.creator_credit: Associated British Picture Corporation, Marcel Hellman and Bruce Humberstone
results.brief_description: This Anglo-American musical/comedy “Happy go lovely” is set in Edinburgh, Scotland, during the Edinburgh festival. A desperate theatre director is staving off creditors and his production hangs in the balance when his leading star quits. None of his crew have been paid properly and are demanding remuneration. Janet Jones (Vera Ellen) is a chorus girl mistaken for the fiancee of local multi-millionaire B.G. Bruno. As a result she is promoted to leading lady and showered in gifts from local dress stores. Rumours drift back to Bruno about Miss Jones and when he calls on her she mistakes him for a reporter, Charlie. As Charlie/Bruno woos Janet complications ensue in a classic case of mistaken identity. The film features numerous song and dance sequences, many of which are in the style of ballet.

results.title: Happy Gilmore
results.creator_credit: MCA/Universal, MCA/Universal Home Video, Robert Simonds and Dennis Dugan
results.brief_description: Happy Gilmore has an anger management problem, which could be really helpful if he could achieve his dream of becoming a professional ice hockey player. However he is a lousy skater. When his beloved grandmother loses her home to the IRS he desperately tries to find a way to raise the money. Quite by accident he discovers that his hockey slap shot translates to an amazingly accurate 400 yard golf tee shot. So he decides to join the pro golf tour, brining his ferocious temper and outlandish antics to the well-tended fairways. Before long he is a media sensation, attracting hordes of followers and news cameras wherever he goes. A rivalry between Happy and nasty golf pro ‘Shooter’ heats up, resulting in a riotous confrontation on the once-hallowed golf links.

results.title: Hans Christian Andersen
results.creator_credit: Samuel Goldwyn Productions, Samuel Goldwyn and Charles Vidor
results.brief_description: The incredibly multi-talented Danny Kaye stars as Hans Christian Andersen, a young cobbler with a special gift for storytelling. We first see Hans in his home town of Odense, Denmark, entertaining the village children with his fascinating tales - much to the displeasure of the schoolmaster. Hans takes off for Copenhagen where he falls hopelessly in love with a ballerina, only to discover she is already married. However, this unrequited love inspires a spectacular 17 minute ballet, “The Little Mermaid”, that is one of the highlights of the film. Finally Hans returns home to the acclaim of his fellow townsfolk. Nominated for six Academy Awards, it is a visual and musical delight with an imaginative score. You will be enchanted by this entertaining and much-loved family film that has delighted both young and old for over forty years.

results.title: Hannah and her sisters
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation, Robert Greenhut and Woody Allen
results.brief_description: An adult and incisively intelligent comedy by Woody Allen. Michael Caine is attracted to his wife’s youngest sister (Barbara Hershey), while his wife (Mia Farrow) is still having trouble with her ex-husband (Woody Allen). Juggling an enormous cast, Allen has produced a rich portrait of the contemporary mores of New York’s professionals and bourgeoisie. Though tackling similar themes to earlier movies, in “Hannah and Her Sisters” Allen develops a stronger emotional tone through his warm celebration of the foibles and struggles of family life. The superb cast also includes Carrie Fisher, Maureen O’Sullivan, Max Van Sydow, Dianne Wiest and Julie Kavner. The jazz score is a stand-out.

results.title: Handsome Serge = Le Beau Serge
results.brief_description: After ten years away, Francois returns to the village where he grew up and meets up with his old friend Serge. Serge used to be the envy of all because of his intelligence and beauty, but he is now only a shadow of his former self. Married to Yvonne, Serge has become an alcoholic after the couple lost their child. Francois is willing to do anything to help his friend, and the two protagonists indulge in a transfer of personal guilt, then an exchange of redemption. “Le Beau Serge” was the first film of French critic-turned-director Claude Chabrol and is widely acknowledged as the first film of the French New Wave. Two of the principal actors - Jean-Claude Brialy and Gerard Blain - also appear in Chabrol’s follow-up film, “Les Cousins”. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Hana-Bi = Fireworks
results.creator_credit: Office Kitano, Masayuki Mori, Yasushi Tsuge, Takio Yoshida and Takeshi Kitano
results.brief_description: ‘Hana-bi’ might of launched director and star Takeshi Kitano onto the international film scene but the prolific film maker (who also goes by the name ‘Beat’ Takeshi) was already a star in his home country where he wears many creative hats. Besides feature films he works extensively in television, is also known as a comedian and has now added painter to his impressive resume. (Kitano’s artwork is on display throughout Hana-bi) Kitano’s genius lies in the radically contrasting rhythm of narrative and style. One minute a poignant and understated drama about a cop (Kitano) and his terminally ill wife (Kayoko Kishimoto), the next an excessively violent police film, punctuated by bloody scenes of mayhem. The two radically different strands are seamlessly bought together by Kitano’s restrained direction, the mosaic editing style, quirky characterisations and the fine musical score by Joe Hisaishi. In Japanese with English subtitles Cast also includes Ren Osugi and Susumu Terajima. (Awards: Golden Lion 1997 Venice Film Festival)
